logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: A couple of nice optimizations avoiding copying a whole Duration when we only need one of the parts.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Avoid copying a 96-bit value when we only need 32 bits. (We may be able to do something similar in OffsetDateTime construction too.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Tiny (and odd) docs fix.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix embarrassing bug in earlier commit. Thank goodness for tests.

logentry.msg: Remove another LocalDateTime constructor, along with LocalInstant.UnixEpoch.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Move all the LocalInstant tests into just LocalInstantTest.cs (which had become empty).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Handle LocalDateTime.FromDateTime slightly differently - don't go via LocalInstant, as we don't really need to. This means LocalInstant.FromDateTime is no longer required.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Correct another typo in the user guide, in the same vein as revison e3534933e608.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Benchmark for DateTime to LocalDateTime conversion.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Correct two typos in the user guide.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: First steps on validating local date/time values: add some Trusted attributes (more to come) and remove two unused LocalDateTime constructors.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Document the 'n' standard pattern for Offset.
As far as I can see, this has been supported since 1.0.
(grafted from 743ea64f9416)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add a document keeping track of the sizes of core types to the developer guide, and add weights to all the developer guide pages.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove 5-digit year parsing from LocalDatePatternParser (and documentation).

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Remove a non-test 'test' accidentally added in revision 16233f163778.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Don't define the DEBUG symbol in the Release Portable configuration of NodaTime.Test.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
First of many commits for improving validation.
- Added [Trusted] to many YearMonthDayCalculator methods; still need to verify that most are correct. - Adjusted the min/max year of all calendars - Added some validation into CalendarSystem, and tests. - Added more validation helper methods.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Add a TrustedAttribute, so I can mark which parameters are expected to already be valid. This is primarily for manual checking for now - eventually it would be nice to be able to use Roslyn to help check that we really have validation.
Additionally, change Preconditions.DebugCheck* to use a specific exception which we won't expect in other calls.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Removed stray using directives.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add a bunch of benchmarks which were missing from OffsetDateTimeBenchmarks for some reason. (This is basically a copy of the LocalDateTimeBenchmarks tests.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Forgot to document that ZonedClock is immutable...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
First stab at a "clock with time zone and calendar" concept. Currently implemented via a decorator, with convenience methods on SystemClock to create useful instances.
Everything about the design is up for discussion. Things to think about:
- Should we expose the clock/zone/calendar as properties? - Should we have a WithClock method for symmetry? - Can we think of some less abhorrent method names in SystemClock?

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Tweak to use the fact that we now have nanosecond precision in Duration.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Fix the URL to point at the Noda Time blog because msmvps.com 503.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Move the somewhat-oddly-placed LocalTime.On method (no functional change).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Change CalendarSystem.GetEra to return the Era rather than just the index.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove references to BCL calendars, to satisfy the PCL build. While it would be possible to conditionalize everything, it would be ugly as the whole member would have to be conditionalized each time :(

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Backed out changeset: ca70fedb22a4 The problem is with the PCL build, where those calendars don't exist.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fully-qualify XML-only references to System.Globalization. It's unclear why this was working locally for me but doesn't work on Bagpuss...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use CommonCalendars in tests etc. Definitely looks nicer.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
I'm fed up with writing CalendarSystem.GetJulianCalendar(4) in tests. It's about time we had a simple property-based way of getting calendars for common cases.
I'm open to new ideas for names, including CalendarFactory. Unfortunately it can't be Calendars as that's the name of a namespace too.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix bug in OffsetDateTime.WithCalendar, where it basically... didn't work properly at all.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add reference to blog post explaining why I've made some fields non-readonly.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Avoid using properties when we don't need to (as that way we can avoid making copies, sometimes). Some of this is overkill, but it's consistent - and in some cases it will make a real difference.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add attribute to indicate the reason for making a field read/write. Eventually we'll have tests to avlidate that it really isn't written anywhere else...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Remove a couple of ZonedDateTime constructors that didn't perform validation: now favour one which takes OffsetDateTime and DateTimeZone directly.
(Also fixed a validation bug, which may also have been present in previous commit...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Make ZonedDateTime just contain an OffsetDateTime and a DateTimeZone, which is sensible - but make most value-type fields within structs non-readonly. This avoids creating a copy of them when calling methods etc, which shaves quite a bit of time off. Now the only reason for having the separate fields within OffsetDateTime (instead of a LocalDateTime and an Offset) is for size - which we still haven't fixed yet. (I think we need a YearMonthDayOffset struct, containing both of the 32-bit structs.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
More optimizations for OffsetDateTime and ZonedDateTime to avoid converting to a LocalDateTime unnecessarily.
Next step is probably to check what would happen if we made ZonedDateTime just OffsetDateTime + DateTimeZone, which would reduce the duplication we've now got. It may well put ZonedDateTime back where it was, as we'd still have the indirection... but you never know.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
More benchmarks for Instant.WithOffset, optimization of OffsetDateTime.WithOffset, and a bit of refactoring of TickArithmetic.
This optimization approach is still experimental. I'll most likely kill it in the morning.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Somewhat experimental optimization. Slows down construction a bit in some cases at the moment (can be tweaked later) but improves other access. Original purpose was to allow us to tweak the padding, but that will need to come later.
This change may well end up being reverted...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add comments for constructors introduced a couple of revisions ago.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove commented-out leftovers from failed optimization attempt.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize InUtc to bypass unnecessary arithmetic (and use it when formatting).

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Replace <inheritdoc/> tags with the documentation that used to be in the ITzdbDataSource interface removed in 6aa4d2aa8cba.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Reduce the number of levels of indirection when creating a ZonedDateTime or OffsetDateTime, by inlining the offset addition code.
This helps locally for a few tested benchmarks, but we'll see what it does for the overall results...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Tweak the caching in date time zones; shifting the number of days since the epoch is much more efficient than converting to ticks and back. Also, check whether the node is a "one interval only" node (which most are) before checking whether the current node contains the instant we're looking for.
(This still doesn't do *much* to ConvertUtcToLocal... there's more to look for, I think.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove ITzdbDataSource, as there was only one implementation left.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add some tests for the recent optimizations, and a comment to come back to.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Improve day -> YMD conversion for the Gregorian calendar by changing the result of the binary search from "month" to "start of month in days". We can then just divide by 29 to get the month, and subtract this from "days from start of year" to get the day of month... no need for an array lookup.
The microbenchmark results, while positive, are probably less important than the bigger result of not pulling an array from the heap into CPU cache.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add benchmarks specifically for constructing dates from "days of epoch", to make it easier to test changes in just that aspect.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Shave about 10% off Instant -> ZonedDateTime in the ISO calendar system, and probably improve other situations, by introducing a new LocalDate(days) constructor which goes straight to the ISO calendar "days to YMD" conversion, bypassing virtual calls etc for the optimized range (1900-2100).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove methods from LocalInstant which aren't important now.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: More plans around ranges.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use the build label to work out which source version we're really looking at.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix previous change which was slightly broken - and make it less confusing, at the same time.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Perform a cruder but cheaper check to see whether a given local time *might* be ambiguous.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Further slight optimization in GetOccurrenceForYear - avoid computing DayOfWeek twice (as this involves converting to day-since-epoch).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use debug preconditions within ZoneLocalMapping.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use unchecked arithmetic in Duration. (We'll need to add a check for the days range in the constructor at some point, but I suspect the range will allow us to be pretty confident within arithmetic...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add a "debug only" precondition - used for checking our own internal preconditions, only within a debug build of Noda Time. These won't be present at all in a release build.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Only do half as many transition lookups when we're asking for a ZoneInterval, just by applying a bit of common sense...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fixes in response to comments on previous revisions.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
We don't *need* to specify the old offset when working out the transition, so why bother? It doesn't seem to make a very significant performance difference, but it can't hurt.
(We might even be able to get rid of Transition entirely, and just use an OffsetDateTime... that can come later.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix test namespaces which I missed when renaming the TzdbCompiler namespace ages ago.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize OffsetDateTime.WithOffset to avoid expensive LocalInstant conversions.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Move the conversion of a character representing a TransitionMode from ZoneYearOffset to the one class which was calling the method.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Simplify ZoneYearOffset so it's really just about getting a transition for a single year. Logic for "next and previous" is now in ZoneRecurrence - which already *had* Next/Previous logic, but delegated some of it. As ZoneRecurrence has the information about the min/max years, this ends up being a bit cleaner.
Lots more to do, but this is a start...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Update OffsetDateTime.Comparer.Local and ZonedDateTime.Comparer.Local to be calendar-sensitive.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove comparison operators from ZonedDateTime.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: First part of fixing up comparisons: LocalDate and LocalDateTime now throw ArgumentException if the values to compare are in different calendars.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: First part of drafting the value range documentation.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix bizarre breakage...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge with Nanoseconds branch (now closed). Ticks are dead - long live nanoseconds!

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add CombineXml project, which is embarrassingly trivial, but helpful. (We should consider requiring script-cs on the build box for this sort of thing...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: First attempt at very crude manual dependency injection.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use static file watchers for the benchmark repository and version log. This is pretty horrible - we should use proper DI. Something to investigate imminently.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Backed out changeset: e2394c192b6a Looks like it was the MVC lifecycle that I didn't understand...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Reload based on size change rather than write time - it looks like the last write time is unreliable.
This isn't a great move in general, but it should be okay for our use cases. If we're still loading the repository each time we hit Machines, it could be a different issue...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix repository loading from a single file... (Took 700ms just loading the file without processing anything. Hopefully that'll be most of the cost...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

Make some plaintext URLs links, and rewrite slightly.

logentry.msg: Add a link to the NZD download page.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Load benchmarks from benchmarks.xml (single file) instead of separate files. If this is quicker, we can automate building benchmarks.xml.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix previous issue recording the loading times...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Record loading time for benchmarks. Not sure why it's taking so long...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
First attempt at a date interval type. Open questions:
- Should this actually be a struct rather than a class? - Is it okay to reject dates in different calendars? (Hoping to make this a prevalent approach.) - Is Length a decent name, or should it be something like Days? - Should we allow serialization? I'm somewhat doubtful, at least for the first release - it's easier to add it later than change it.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Reported results of performance experiment.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix embarrassing bug in Period.AddTo(LocalDateTime). Added test :)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Tiny optimizations to avoid as many nullity checks for LocalDate construction.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Inline TimeOfDayCalculator methods into LocalTime. (Each was only being called from a single property.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix embarrassing removal of PeriodUnits.Hours from builder...

logentry.msg: Make all operations in TimeOfDayCalculator unchecked.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove unused code from TimeOfDayCalculator. The whole class can probably be folded into LocalTime now.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Change Preconditions.CheckArgumentRange back to not returning the value. We were only using it in one place, which actually looks cleaner without it anyway.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Micro-optimize LocalTime by only calling Preconditions.CheckArgumentRange when we know we need to.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Merge.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: We already have code to compute days from ticks efficiently, so let's use it.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Use unchecked operations for Year/Month/Day properties.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Optimize construction of a LocalDate defaulting to the ISO calendar system:
- Don't validate that CalendarSystem.ISO isn't null - Use a static validation call rather than a virtual one - Don't work out the number of days in the month unless the specified day is more than 28.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix previous commit, which was broken. Add tests too :)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Avoid creating a whole LocalDateTime when we only want the date of a LocalInstant. In fact, we only need the year, which means we *could* optimize further if we really wanted to.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize WeekYearCalculator: unchecked FTW.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimizations of methods at the heart of the YearMonthDay, and particularly the Gregorian calendar.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Allow wildcards on the end of method names. (May do this for types too, or make them regexes.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix bizarre unwanted import.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Improve performance of year/month/day validation for Gregorian and Julian calendars, which significantly increases LocalDate construction performance.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Slight optimization of GetDaysInMonth for GJYearMonthDayCalculator.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Move WeekYearCalculator code around to make it top-to-bottom (i.e. nothing ever calls code higher than it). That should be helpful for future refactoring.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Small but surprisingly-effective optimization of WeekYear/WeekOfWeekYear.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Slight tidy-ups.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimization of PlusDays.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Stop setting a sticky-session cookie on every browser.
(This is a reapplication of r1507d3cc9d85 to the Web.config location that we're actually using now.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix ArgumentOutOfRangeException in HebrewScripturalCalculator for PCL.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Refactor YearMonthDayCalculator to take the same approach for all calendars - GetYearMonthDay(int daysSinceEpoch) is now in the base class, and works out the year and day-of-year, then gets the subclasses to work out the month/day based on those.
This involved a major refactor of the Hebrew calendar code, which simplified it *and* made it faster (with room for further optimization...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add a benchmark for the HebrewCalendarSystem, just to convert each day of a leap cycle to ISO and back. This is a pretty coarse benchmark, but it should be enough to prove whether or not optimizations around other calendars are awful for the Hebrew calendar.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize time fields and day field.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize GetDayOfYear - we already know the year/month/day, and we can get the day-of-start-of-month from that.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.msg: Merge

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.msg: First (huge) step refactoring the `LocalDate` representating to year-month-day. Performance comparisons between this and the build on June 19th 2014 will be interesting...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Refactor period arithmetic into separate date and time pieces. Some more work required here, as time-based arithmetic on LocalDateTime will ideally work on a "day count" version of the date rather than just LocalDate.
(And putting more code into Between(LocalDate*2) and Between(LocalTime*2) should optimize it quite a bit.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Avoid using the culture-specific decimal separator *anywhere*. We were using it to detect when we needed to truncate fractional seconds, but we were already using "." in all cases as the separator for formatting. This inconsistency meant that sometimes we could end up with a trailing . incorrectly.
(Additionally, we were using the current culture's text comparison rules, which probably wasn't a good idea.)
Finally, the new code is almost certainly more efficient too, although that's not particularly relevant.
This fixes issue 273.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Add the idea of a "category" to benchmarks, so that categories can be included or excluded. This allows us to exclude all BCL tests on Mono.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Optimize numeric parsing by inlining digit checking and the temporary indexes. (MoveNext was taking a surprising amount of the time.) This improves parsing speed by about 10% on the test I happened to be running. (Will see what impact it has on other tests and on x86 later...)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Refactoring of YearMonthDayCalculator to use days instead of ticks as the unit of calculation. This allows a cache which is day based and stores everything in 32 bits... which means we can rely on atomic access, and no locking.
Added a couple of benchmarks to LocalDateTest to stretch it slightly more.
Removed the idea of a "safe" GetYearTicks from a "normal" one - we were doing multiple identical tests for no obvious reason. We assume that any caller will already be validating the year where appropriate. This needs checking.

Point the User Guide roadmap sections at a new duplicate of the roadmap in the Developer Guide. It's confusing to keep around different versions of a 'current' roadmap, and directing people to an online version seems like a sensible idea.
Note that 1.0.x apparently did not have a roadmap.
(I also considered choosing one version of the user guide to be the 'canonical' one, and forwarding the others. However, the obvious location for a canonical version is either 'latest stable' or 'unstable', both of which would be problematic. This seemed easier, and has the advantage of putting the roadmap next to the people doing the work.)

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Always include the local system time zone ID in the collection returned by GetIds(), even if it's not present in TimeZoneInfo.GetSystemTimeZones(), as it will generally not be on Mono (when not running on Windows).
In that case, the time zone ID will the unhelpful "Local", but at least DateTimeZoneProviders.Bcl.GetSystemDefault() will return a DateTimeZone rather than failing.
Fixes issue 235.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Change Json.NET to use DurationPattern instead of NodaDurationConverter (which can now die).
The new converter can handle anything created by the old converter and vice versa, but they will produce different strings in some cases, as the old converter always formatted subsecond values straight down to the tick or down to the millisecond, producing trailing zeroes where necessary. The new converter removes insignificant trailing zeroes. For example, "1.500" will now be "1.5", and "1.1234000" will now be "1.1234".

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Implement DurationPattern, and make it implement IFormattable in a fairly obvious way. This involves some localized grotty hacks to round-trip long.MinValue ticks, and a poorly-chosen pattern will still overflow for large durations; this is unlikely to be a problem though.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Reverse earlier decision to use "rrrr" as a "4 or 5 digit year". Instead, we're smarter with yyyy, detecting when it's safe to parse 5 digits instead of 4.
We should probably do the same with "year of era" too...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.msg: Fix JSON serialization for ZonedDateTime to use rrrr.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Introduce the "rrrr" custom date format, which is like yyyy but will format and parse any absolute year; it also consumes up to 5 digits, so should not be used in compact patterns: rrrr-MM-dd is fine, but rrrrMMdd is full of fail.
This is necessary in order to round-trip values outside the range [-9999, 9999].

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Throw ArgumentOutOfRangeException when formatting with yyyy and given a year more than 9999 or earlier than -9999.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:

Mono doesn't implement TimeZoneInfo.GetUtcOffset(DateTimeOffset), though it does implement TimeZoneInfo.GetUtcOffset(DateTime).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
- Adjust the previously vague approxTicksAtEpochDividedByTwo to ticksAtStartOfYear1, and use accordingly.
- Simplify the process of finding a year so that we don't need to get to within 1 year in the first estimate. I can now understand this code :)
- Make IslamicYearMonthDayCalculator handle years outside its normal range better.
- Remove special-casing in IslamicYearMonthDayCalculator, so there's less code to understand. We may see slightly worse performance, but we can optimize that later. (It may improve performance for other calendars, as a previously-virtual method is now non-virtual. Unlikely to be significant though.)
- Tests to check that each calculator is consistent in finding the ticks for a year and finding the year from a LocalInstant.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

- Added some more LocalTime benchmarks - Renamed DivRem in TimeOfDayCalculator - Made arithmetic in TimeOfDayCalculator unchecked - Organized using directives
We checked performance of using Int32 remainder arithmetic and also going directly to TimeOfDayCalculator within LocalTime; the differences weren't significant enough to warrant the ugliness in either case.

Add a header and footer containing next/previous links to the generated user and developer guides, along with an auto-generated TOC and version number.
This changes some titles to be a bit more consistent between TOC and section title, but otherwise is essentially a no-op as far as content is concerned.
Note that this doesn't add an 'Up' link to each page, but after playing about for a while, I'm not sure that's worthwhile.
Fixes issue 127.

Add a black-box test to ensure that we can read the NodaZoneData file generated by ZoneInfoCompiler for 1.1.0.
This isn't actually necessary right now, as the stream format hasn't changed since 1.1, but if we ever do change it (as we expect to do for 1.3), this would be the test we'd want to add.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Be consistent in how we refer to the tz database, by e.g. not calling it "tzdb aka Olson" in one place, "tzdb aka zoneinfo" in another, and "zoneinfo aka tz or Olson" in a third.
(I've picked "tz database" as the main descriptor since we call it "TZDB" in a large number of places, and because that's what Wikipedia calls it.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Added the "x" specifier for ZonedDateTimePattern, to format the time zone abbreviation (at the instant being formatted). This also introduces the idea of a pattern being "format-only" - it will immediately fail if it is asked to parse anything.
A few aspects of this should provoke discussion: - The choice of "x" as a specifier - The format-only nature (to avoid ambiguity; we could have an ambiguity resolver or something like that, potentially) - The exception thrown on parsing (currently UnparseableValueException, but could be InvalidOperationException)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
First commit for XML serialization. The two serialization projects (prod and test) now need a reference to System.Xml as they refer to Noda Time types which now implement IXmlSerializable - ironically the serialization projects themselves don't touch XML serialization. This needs to be carefully considered in terms of backwards compatibility.
Additionally, this code uses the nasty approach of assigning to "this" in ReadXml. Suggest we discuss this before proceeding with the other types (which should be fairly easy).

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Ensure we can handle first and last years better. Various internal calls need to be able to handle the year before the advertised minimum and the year after the advertised maximum, to adjust original estimates.
I've therefore revised our min/max values to be slightly more conservative. Arguably this is a breaking change, but as the previous code couldn't handle the extreme values anyway, I'm only changing how breakage would be observed.
We still have work to do around ensuring any value of a public type is within appropriate bounds.
Fixes issue 197.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Rewrite (and simplification of) the NodaZoneData serialised form for zone interval transitions.
Briefly, instead of wrangling bits directly, we encode a varint whose value we interpret as either 'special', 'number of hours since previous transition', or 'number of minutes since epoch', depending on the value. (The 'special' case can be followed by a fixed64 instant to handle the unusual cases.)
This reduces the size of the NodaZoneData output by about 10% (~13KB).
[Unfortunately, this does mean that the general-use {Read,Write}Instant() methods are now {Read,Write}ZoneIntervalTransition(), and take a 'previous value read/written' parameter, making them slightly less general.]
Closes issue 181.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Simplify the (NodaZoneDate) serialised form of ZoneYearOffset to encode (possibly-negative) day-of-month using zigzag encoding.
This is somewhat unnecessary at present, but avoids the need to document a bias value (and leads to a somewhat simpler format to document, especially if we start to use this anywhere else).
This does not affect the size of the NodaZoneData file at all, though it does make it marginally easier to interpret by hand.

Introduce a new exception (DateTimeZoneNotFoundException) and use it across both the PCL and the desktop. The base class on the desktop version is TimeZoneNotFoundException; on the PCL it's just Exception. The new type only exists because TimeZoneNotFoundException doesn't exist in the PCL.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Change the (NodaZoneData) serialised form of ZoneYearOffset to encode month-of-year and day-of-week directly as counts [1,12] and [0,7] respectively, instead of first adding a bias in case the values are negative (they never are - unlike day-of-month, which uses negative values to indicate counting from the end of the month).
This does not affect the size of the NodaZoneData file at all - it just makes the serialised form more straightforward.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg: Correct the name of the NodaZoneData resource type option.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Don't include a mapping of "canonical ID to canonical ID" in the serialized format. Every canonical ID will map to itself, so why include it?
(This doesn't slim things down much, but it's irked me for ages.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Rewrite of ReadInstant/WriteInstant, with a new format. This takes advantage of the fact that we quite often have whole numbers of hours, and that everything in TZDB is after 1800.
The previous documentation for WriteTicks/ReadTicks was somewhat broken in terms of both the limits and the length of fields. Hopefully the new documentation is clearer.
The result is that Tzdb.nzd is now ~20% smaller.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
1. Unconditionally include the blob format in NodaTime.dll, rather than the resx format.
2. For backward compatibility, constructor calls which would have loaded Tzdb.resx from NodaTime.dll now load the blob format. (Any other request for resources is unaffected.)
3. Remove FromResource calls as we plan on getting rid of the resource format ASAP anyway.
4. Add back TzdbDateTimeZoneSource(ResourceManager) constructor which was in 1.0.
5. Make blob format the default for ZoneInfoCompiler.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Disable a bunch of build targets in the Release Portable configuration.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Fix bug in previous commit, where if we wrote a minute value, we'd *also* write the second value.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Make the WriteOffset/ReadOffset code simpler and very slightly more space-efficient.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Use a simpler WriteCount method. This is *slightly* less efficient than the original version, but easier to follow when examining a file by hand - it's just a simple 7-bit encoding with the high bit as a continuation bit.
(The old version allowed values up to 0x8d to be written in a single byte.)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Remove diagnostics accidentally left in earlier commit.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Added 2012j TZDB data and regenerated both formats, using Windows mapping 22.1.
I've tracked down the difference to the previous TZDB version - it was due to writing year 0 as the "from" year for ZoneRecurrence instead of negative values. It should still be absolutely fine, including with old data... but it's nice to understand it!

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Initial optimizations of stream format:
- Use an optimized string pool, by doing a dry-run first to find out which strings will be used most often
- Get rid of the caching flag; precalculated and DST time zones should always be cached; this shouldn't be part of the serialization information.
None of this *should* have changed the resx format (that's the point of the isolation), but it appears to have done so. Will investigate that separately.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: The LegacyDateTimeZoneReader/Writer pair should only use its own flags.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
First pass of separating the legacy resource format from the new stream format. Moving forward, we'll only rely on IDateTimeZone{Writer,Reader} members, and can assume a global string pool.
For some reason the current implementation has created a *bigger* nzd file - I need to dig into why that is (as it's probably a mistake).
I haven't tried to keep test coverage yet - before we're done, we definitely need to test both the legacy and new paths fairly comprehensively.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Introduce interfaces (currently unimplemented) for reading/writing. This commit is mostly so I can switch to another machine :)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Remove WriteLocalInstant/ReadLocalInstant (as they weren't used), and make WriteTicks/ReadTicks private (as they were only used within the same class).
We could further elide WriteTicks/ReadTicks into WriteInstant/ReadInstant, but we can do that a bit later. This revision mostly tries to limit the internal API surface.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Moved DateTimeZoneBuilder, ZoneRecurrenceCollection and ZoneTransition into the ZoneInfoCompiler project. Minor refactoring around PrecalculatedDateTimeZone was required (a single constructor referred to ZoneTransition) but that's all.
Additionally, ZoneTransition no longer implements equality or comparisons. We weren't using them in ZoneInfoCompiler, and the type was internal anyway, so this is safe.
This change has been validated by rebuilding Tzdb.nzd and checking that the file contents haven't changed.
This fixes issue 162.

logentry.author: Richard Schneider
logentry.msg:
Fixed issue 116 - default constructors.
Using the default constructor (parameter-less) on a struct sets any reference fields to null. We cannot override this behaviour nor make our own default constructor!
Types LocalDateTime and ZonedDateTime have reference fields, calendar and zone respectively, that should not be null. The getter property has been changed to null-coalescing the default value. Accesss the reference field has been changed to using the getter property.
LocalDateTime.Calendar defaults to CalendarSystem.Iso and ZonedDateTime.Zone defaults DateTimeZone.Utc.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Remove NodaCultureInfo, and make NodaFormatInfo internal. Fixes issue 131.
This removes the ability to set a custom default format for Noda Time-specific objects, or specify custom formats for compound formatters, but avoids tying us in to known-broken behaviour for 1.x (see e.g. issues 96, 130, 133).
Also: - Removed the special-casing for NodaFormatInfo.Clone() that had to update the reflexive reference from a NodaCultureInfo. - Removed the FormatInfo property and WithFormatInfo() method on pattern types. - Changed the culture-specific pattern factory methods to take a CultureInfo rather than a NodaFormatInfo. - Removed the section on semi-mutable reference types from the user guide (which was only really talking about NodaFormatInfo and NodaCultureInfo).

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Remove the concept of missing vs zero values from Period. Fixes issue 90.
This removes the Units property entirely, makes the Year (etc) properties on PeriodBuilder non-nullable, and changes period formatting to unconditionally exclude zero-valued properties.
It also changes the internal representation of a Period from (units, long value, long[] values) to individual (year, month, weeks, ...) fields.
The optimisation of using a single value in some cases seems unlikely to help - we believe that most Period instances will be composite - and while the generic long[] representation is helpful (and is still used temporarily in a few places), the more explicit layout leads to less indirection in many cases (at some cost to verbosity, it's true).
Also: - Renamed Period.Empty to Period.Zero. - Documented that Period.Normalize() can throw OverflowException. (Fixes issue 92)

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Fix issue 74: document nullability (and null-ness) consistently.
Remove any 'must not be null'-style text in parameter descriptions, replacing it with exception documentation for ArgumentNullException instead. (There may be cases where ArgumentNullException is not documented, and should be, but this is enough to close this issue.)
Also consistently use the plaintext 'null' in documentation rather than <c>null</c> or <see langword="null"/>, and consistently use '[param] is null.' as the description for ArgumentNullException.
Finally, remove bogus documentation for a few Equals() methods that documented that NullReferenceException would be thrown if called with null (it shouldn't, and wouldn't - except in the case of ZoneAlias, where we fix that as a bug).

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Partially fix issue 65, documenting the (stricter) requirements on providers and sources to return equal time zones given equal inputs, as a step to fixing issue 81. This also partially reverts some changes from revision 3546ef81087c.
Document that:
- DateTimeZone implementations should implement IEquatable; this will be implemented in issue 81. - DateTimeZone.ForOffset returns an instance equal to DateTimeZone.Utc for offset zero, and returns equal (but not necessarily identical) instances given the same input offsets. - Providers and sources must return equal instances given the same input ID. - Providers (and sources, if applicable) must return an instance equal to that returned by ForOffset() for the fixed-offset timezone IDs. - DateTimeZoneCache will not consult the source for the fixed-offset timezones; this remains to be implemented to close this issue.

logentry.author: Malcolm Rowe
logentry.msg:
Fix for issue 65, clarifying how providers interact with built-in fixed-offset timezones, along with more clarifications for some of the consquences.
Document that:
- DateTimeZone instances may be equivalent without being identical. This is already true of the uncached fixed-offset timezones (which do have value equality), and is also true of DateTimeZone.Utc and IDateTimeZoneProvider["UTC"] (which may not, and do not in the case of the BCL provider).
- Providers (and sources) may optionally advertise the fixed-offset timezones in the advertised list, and that, regardless of their presence, providers always support (sources, on the other hand, do not).
- DateTimeZoneCache will always prefer the source over the built-in implementations for the fixed-offset timezones.
- Lookups by ID may return a DateTimeZone with a different ID. (This is true of fixed-offset timezones now: looking up "UTC+05:00:00" returns a timezone with ID "UTC+05" - and will also [probably] be true if aliases are supported.)
- Although a provider (and source) are not obliged to cache timezones by ID, they must return equivalent timezones for the same requested ID.
The wording around 'equivalent' timezones is something we may wish to revisit in the future; in particular, it makes ZonedDateTime's equality implementation look slightly dodgy.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet

Rename tests to match the type they're testing.
Where we want multiple "sets" of test for a single production class, we can use partial classes with dependencies in the project file. See LocalDateTest for an example of this.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg: Make null values more obviously null - give the variable an explicit type, so we can use the null literal. Likewise use Assert.IsNull instead of creating a new variable with a null value and then Assert.AreEqual.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Go back to using an individual converter where possible, and explicitly showing which converters are required otherwise (e.g. for IntervalTests).
We should actually document the dependencies, i.e. that NodaIntervalConverter requires that some sort of Instant converter is bound (although that doesn't have to be NodaInstantConverter).
I would rather keep this explicit in the tests than just have "it all works if it's all bound."

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Turn "const string" into "string" in all tests.
I personally can't remember the last time I saw any value in using "const" within a method. Yes, it stops you from changing the value of the local variable - but from a readability standpoint, these methods are all so small that that's obvious anyway. It's not like it's *just* making the variable readonly, as it's only available for compile-time constant values. So where's the benefit?
(I know R# suggests it. I would suggest turning that suggestion off :)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Remove Arrange/Act/Assert comments from each test. They just end up being noise - if you know every test (or at least most tests) will follow that pattern anyway, we shouldn't need to be reminded about it every single time.
I've left blank lines where it's perhaps less obvious where each phase starts, but collapsed some completely (e.g. InstantTests).
Note that personally I'm often happy to collapse two phases into one, when they're trivial - for example, calling the method under test with an argument which constructs the relevant value then and there, rather than always having a separate variable first. I won't object to having the phases separated so long as they're not too chatty, but don't expect all other tests to follow the same line of reasoning :)

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Rename test methods. We already know the type involved and that we're dealing with Json.NET, based on the namespace and the test type name.
The important information is usually:
- The operation we're testing (which is a little indirect here anyway) - The nullability of the type involved (Foo or Nullable<Foo>) - Something about the value
Note that almost all these tests look the same - they can all be represented really easily with a base class which is configured with a non-null value and an expected representation. That'll come later.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Significant changes to time zone creation to fix issue 27.
Basic changes:
- "Advance" wasn't always being maintained - The "until" part of a zone line is now parsed as a ZoneYearOffset - When building a precalculated zone, ignore the last transition other than to find the starting point of the daylight zone - Fixes to transition validation
Fewer tests than I'd like, and the code is still more confusing than I'd like... but it does seem to work.

Fix for issue 29 - use a single provider in TimeZoneCache, which can be replaced by DateTimeZone.SetProvider.
If we ever *do* want multiple active providers, we can easily achieve that using a CompoundProvider.

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Fix for issue 28 - handle fixed negative offsets.
ZoneTransition previously adjusted its offset to make sure that computation of the local instant at the start of the transition would succeed; that then left the offset incorrect for other times. We now keep the offset without any checking, but provide a LocalInstant property which rounds on overflow.
All of this requires a new time zone database, as the error occurred while creating it.

Refactoring to separate calendars which wrap others from ones which don't.
At the same time I've had to change the way fields are initialised. I'm still not really happy with this... I'm trying to work out a better way of attacking the problem. The problem comes from two requirements for field construction: - The need to store the "current" calendar (in BasicCalendarSystem) - The need to access a constructor parameter (baseCalendar) in WrappedCalendarSystem.cs
Fortunately all of this mess is internal...

logentry.author: Jon Skeet
logentry.msg:
Store the min and max offsets as ticks, and add them manually.
We internally store Offset values as milliseconds so that we can use an int field instead of a long; this means we need to perform a multiplication every time we add one, which we do on every GetZoneIntervals call. We may wish to investigate the benefit of introducing a TickOffset type for places where we're going to use the same offset regularly in this way, only for classes where we're not creating new instances very often (e.g. ZoneRecurrence and *possibly* ZoneInterval).

Fixed several problems with the TimeZone compiler and especially the compression/decompression code.
Added many more tests to validate the TimeZone compiler and the compression/decompression code.

Tried various different compression algorithms and surprise, surprise the version from JodaTime (with a slight adjustment) was the best.

logentry.author: James Keesey
logentry.msg: Fixed problem where Release code wouldn't compile. Unfortunately, when you use the Remove and Sort usings command it doesn't look at code that is inside a #if/#else/#endif for references to namespaces. Fixed by appending the full namespace to the items in both parts of the #if. Now compiles under Release and Debug.

logentry.author: James Keesey
logentry.msg: Changed Offset to use an Int32 number of milliseconds instead of an Int64 number of ticks. Unlike Duration where intervals of single ticks makes sense, Offsets describe the offset of a time zone from UTC and no time zone uses more than one second resolution so milliseconds are more than enough.

logentry.author: James Keesey
logentry.msg:
Added writing and reading of IDatetimeZones and hooked up the ZoneInfoCompiler to write the time zones it generates out. Currently the output format is as byte[] in resource files. If should be possible to change that if necessary but it make loading them from the assembly simpler. Currently only loading from the assembly is supported but will be adding support for loading from external files in the future.
At this point there is still much to do but I'm opening up everything I've done for code reviewing if you want. If you see anything that is really ugly and without comments then I probably havent' gotten there yet so be kind. I'm still in the process of reformatting the code to match the "will of the people" but I may have missed a few files.

logentry.author: configurator
logentry.msg:
- Capitalized property name SingleFieldPeriodBaseTest.Value - Added 'new' to definition of Days.Value
This makes the code CLS-compliant (previously there was a name clash between protected value and public Value. Even though it's impossible to see both names at the same time - the class is sealed - it's still a violation of CLS. Now the public name hides the protected name, so there is no problem)
